title: Worked Solution
text:
To find the equation of the line passing through two points, we need to first find the slope, which is given by:

$$m$$ $$=$$ (y2 - y1)/(x2 - x1)

where (x1, y1) $$=$$ $$(3,4)$$ and (x2, y2) $$=$$ $$(0,-3)$$

$$m$$ $$=$$ (-3 - 4)/(0 - 3) $$=$$ $$ rac{-7}{3}$$

Now we can use the point-slope form of the equation of a line, which is:

$$y$$ - y1 $$=$$ m(x - x1)

where (x1, y1) $$=$$ $$(3,4)$$ and $$m$$ $$=$$ $$ rac{-7}{3}$$

$$y$$ - $$4$$ $$=$$ (-7/3)(x - 3)

Finally, we can rearrange this equation into slope-intercept form, which is:

$$y$$ $$=$$ mx + $$b$$

where $$m$$ is the slope and $$b$$ is the y-intercept

$$y$$ - $$4$$ $$=$$ $$\left(- rac{7}{3}ight) x$$ + $$7$$

$$y$$ $$=$$ $$\left(- rac{7}{3}ight) x$$ + $$11$$

Therefore, the equation of the line passing through the points $$(3,4)$$ and $$(0,-3)$$ is $$y=\left(- rac{7}{3}ight) x+11$$.
